question:
You are called to assess a term newborn on day 1 of life, after the paediatrician fails to insert an nasogastric tube. A chest radiograph demonstrates coiling of the nasogastric tube in the neck, and a gasless abdomen 

What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.D: Common type oesophageal atresia with mucus plugging of the distal tracheoesophageal fistula

answer_rationale: The most likely diagnosis is oesophageal atresia with no tracheoesophageal fistula (this occurs in 7% of cases of oesopheageal atresia). Iatrogenic oesophageal perforation and oesophageal stenosis are differentials for the finding of a coiled nasogastric tube however one would expect to see air in the stomach/ abdomen. Whilst it is possible to has a gasless abdomen in common type OA/TOF due to mucus plugging of the TOF, this is rare.

A 74-year old male is referred to your hospital with a diagnosis of "appendicitis" listed in a note from the referring hospital. He has pain and tenderness in the right abdomen. He has vomited several times over the course of the past 2 days. He has a temperature of 37.5°C. His family states that he has lost some weight over the past few weeks; they don't think he's been eating as well asusual. He is tender on physical examination but without rebound or guarding. His white blood cellcount is normal. What is the next best step in your management?

options.A: Admit the patient for antibiotics and serial abdominal exams.
options.D: Proceed to the operating room for appendectomy
options.E: Proceed with ultrasound to rule out appendicitis.
